channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘I’ve Become a Racist’: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity
item.media:description: A bus stop in Norrebro, a multicultural neighborhood in Copenhagen. More than 36,000 asylum seekers, mostly Muslims, have poured into Denmark over the past two years.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: The thousands of Muslim asylum seekers pouring into Denmark have spawned a backlash, and questions over whether the country has a latent racial hostility at its core.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Keith Vaz, British Lawmaker, Quits Senior Post Amid Sex and Drug Scandal
item.media:description: The constituency office of Keith Vaz, a high-ranking Labour Party lawmaker, in Leicester, England, on Sunday.
item.description: The high-profile Labour politician resigned as head of a Home Office oversight committee after a tabloid reported he had met two men working as prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: French Prime Minister Faults Times Article Giving Voice to Muslim Women
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France in August. In an opinion piece published on The Huffington Post’s French website, he said a New York Times article in which French Muslim women described discrimination against them presented an “unacceptable image of France because it is false.”
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls wrote that the piece, in which French Muslim women described being discriminated against, painted an “unacceptable image of France because it is false.”
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: In Philippine Drug War, Little Help for Those Who Surrender
item.media:description: Manila residents in a Zumba class. Many turned themselves in for drug abuse, but such workouts are often the extent of the help they receive.
item.media:credit: Nacho Hernandez for The New York Times
item.description: An estimated 687,000 drug users have turned themselves in since President Rodrigo Duterte took office, but the government is proving unprepared to assist them.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: New Karachi Mayor Gets Brief Prison Furlough to Be Sworn In
item.media:description: Waseem Akhtar in an armored vehicle returning him to prison after he was sworn in as mayor of Karachi, Pakistan, last week.
item.description: The election of Waseem Akhtar to lead the city of 22 million comes as his Muttahida Qaumi Movement and its exiled leader are under fire from Pakistan’s military.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Chinese Company’s Payment to Lawmaker Sets Off Furor in Australia
item.media:description: Senator Sam Dastyari of the Labor Party in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday. In the last week, he has faced intense pressure over a Chinese company’s donation of about $1,270.
item.description: Senator Sam Dastyari apologized for accepting the $1,270 donation, which has provoked charges that foreign donors are buying political influence.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Tel Aviv Journal: Guerrilla Art Exhibit Unmasks the Face of Terrorism
item.media:description: The site of an attack in Tel Aviv on Jan. 1. On Monday, a guerrilla art exhibition projected scenes from the attack on giant screens over Dizengoff Square, near where the shootings took place.
item.description: Above Dizengoff Square, a killer’s face and hateful words are on display as part of an Israeli philanthropist’s mission to get his country to confront terrorism.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Syrian Forces Make Gains Near Aleppo With Russian Help
item.media:description: A Syrian government tank took aim on Sunday at the southern outskirts of the city of Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: Russian airstrikes aided the advance, as officials from Russia and the United States reportedly tried to negotiate access for humanitarian aid to the city.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Memo From South Africa: A.N.C.’s Combative Response to Election Losses Startles South Africa
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa in Durban in March. With little explanation, Mr. Zuma recently announced that he would directly oversee the state enterprises that have long been the source of public corruption.
item.description: The country’s governing party has brushed aside calls to replace President Jacob Zuma, raising doubts about another African liberation movement.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: South Sudan to Allow More U.N. Peacekeepers, but Force Will Be No ‘Panacea’
item.description: An American official warned there was only so much the troops could do in a country beleaguered by civilian massacres, rape and the destruction of food supplies.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Abroad in America: An Ugly Presidential Race Shows the World What It’s Missing
item.media:description: Controversies, mostly centered on Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, have dominated the news media this summer.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump enter the final nine weeks of a U.S. presidential campaign that has defied the expectations of both the American electorate and international observers.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Hillary Clinton Says She Won’t Visit Mexico Before Election
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico and Donald J. Trump in Mexico City last week.
item.description: Mrs. Clinton’s decision is likely to prolong the criticism that President Enrique Peña Nieto has faced at home for choosing to meet with Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Letter From Europe: U.N. Chief Presses to Unlock Mystery of Dag Hammarskjold’s Death
item.media:description: The site of the plane crash that killed Dag Hammarskjold in a forest near Ndola, in what was then called Northern Rhodesia, now Zambia, in September 1961.
item.description: Britain and the United States have stonewalled requests by Ban Ki-moon to divulge information on the plane crash that killed his predecessor in 1961.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Obama Acknowledges Scars of America’s Shadow War in Laos
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines at the Asean Summit in Vientiane, Laos, on Tuesday.
item.description: President Obama did not formally apologize for the bombs that the United States had dropped on the country but said that it would raise its aid to Laos.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Shariah With Chinese Characteristics: A Scholar Looks at the Muslim Hui
item.media:description: Relatives riding in a truck with the body of an elderly Hui woman at a funeral in Linxia, a base for Islam in northwestern China.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Matthew S. Erie’s findings about the Hui ethnic group confound many preconceptions about Shariah, Chinese law and the rigidity of the Communist state.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Overnight Assault on Charity in Kabul Has Ended, Afghan Officials Say
item.description: Six people were wounded in the attack on the CARE International compound, the government said, and three militants were killed.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: How Laos Tries to Balance Its Powerful Neighbors
item.media:description: Patrolling at the site of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations gathering in Vientiane, Laos. President Obama will be among those in attendance.
item.description: As the country hosts a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a university lecturer discusses its interactions with China, Vietnam and Thailand.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Blasts ‘Demagogues’ of Western Nations
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations’ high commissioner for human rights, in February.
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein lashed out at Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee for president, and at others like Geert Wilders, a Dutch politician who is anti-Muslim.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Russian Polling Center Is Declared a ‘Foreign Agent’ Before Elections
item.media:description: Lev D. Gudkov, the director of the Levada Center, Russia’s only major independent pollster.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The independent Levada Center, which has conducted surveys since the late 1980s, recently reported declining support for the governing United Russia party.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Theresa May Rules Out Immigration Plan That ‘Brexit’ Backers Espoused
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain arriving at a news conference after the closing of the Group of 20 summit meeting in China on Monday.
item.description: The British prime minister rejected a points-based system in giving her first, tentative details on plans for Britain’s withdrawal, but remained fuzzy on much else.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: After Obama Cancels Talk, Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Says He Regrets Slur
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines arriving in Laos on Monday for a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which President Obama also planned to attend.
item.description: The Philippine leader had used coarse language in warning President Obama not to ask about extrajudicial killings at their scheduled meeting in Laos this week.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Researchers Confront an Epidemic of Loneliness
item.description: Social isolation is linked to physical illness and to functional and cognitive decline. Programs to reach out to the elderly are growing, particularly in Britain.
item.dc:creator: KATIE HAFNER

item.title: Letter From Europe: Does the Messaging Service Telegram Take Privacy Too Far?
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, a founder of the Telegram messaging application, in 2015. He left his native Russia in 2014 after refusing to give intelligence information about Ukrainian protesters.
item.description: Telegram, favored by the Islamic State because of its formidable privacy controls, is a source of consternation for antiterrorism investigators.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Coordinated Bombs in Kabul Kill Senior Afghan Officials at Defense Ministry
item.description: An army general and police security chief were among the dead in a Taliban assault at rush hour. Just before midnight, another blast shook central Kabul.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Merkel Vows to Stay on Course Despite Party Setback
item.description: The German leader’s party placed third in state elections, beaten on the right over her refugee policy and defeated on the left as well.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: At World Scrabble Championship, ‘Braconid’ Carries the Day
item.media:description: Brett Smitheram during the final game of the World Scrabble Championship 2016 against Mark Nyman in Lille, France, on Sunday.
item.description: Good for 176 points, the word for a type of parasitic wasp helped a London recruitment consultant take the top prize of 7,000 euros.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: ‘Gaps of Trust’ With Russia Bar a Syrian Truce, Obama Says
item.media:description: President Obama met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, on the sidelines of the Group of 20 meeting in Hangzhou, China.
item.description: After a meeting with Russia’s president at the Group of 20 summit meeting failed, President Obama said he had told Secretary of State John Kerry to continue negotiating.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Vote in Hong Kong Deepens a Thorn in China’s Side
item.media:description: Nathan Law, right, and supporters celebrating on Monday after he won a seat on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong. He was a leader of the protests that closed major thoroughfares in 2014.
item.description: The election of six freethinking young legislators means that Beijing must deal with an indigenous movement elevated to positions of political power.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Gentler Chicken Slaughter? Chinese Province Thinks It’s Worth a Try
item.media:description: Dead chickens at a slaughterhouse in Shanghai. Shandong Province has issued China’s first guidelines for the more humane killing of chickens.
item.description: New voluntary guidelines in Shandong Province are motivated at least as much by commercial considerations as by concerns for animal welfare.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: London Burns, for the Sake of Art
item.description: A replica of the city’s skyline was set ablaze as part of a festival marking the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: North Korea Test-Fires 3 Missiles Toward Japan, Seoul Says
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at the opening ceremony for the Group of 20 summit meeting in Hangzhou, China, on Sunday.
item.description: The missiles landed in the sea 125 to 155 miles west of Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan’s main islands, the Japanese Ministry of Defense said.
item.dc:creator: SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: Australian Teenager Sentenced to 10 Years in Jail for Anzac Day Terror Plot
item.description: Sevdet Ramadan Besim, 19, planned to run over and behead a police officer during a parade in Melbourne for the national holiday in 2015.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Shanghai Violin Competition Celebrates Isaac Stern’s Legacy in China
item.media:description: The Japanese violinist Mayu Kishima was awarded the first prize at the inaugural Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition on Friday.
item.media:credit: Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition
item.description: Mr. Stern’s visit to China, in 1979, is credited with having influenced a generation of young Chinese musicians.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.category: Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition

item.title: What in the World: In the Land of the Robot, Androids Are on the March
item.description: A handful of androids now greet visitors at a shopping mall and entertain on television. The company that made them plans to add them by the thousands.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: What in the World: Malta’s Walls Are Covered in Murals, and Street Art Is Covered in Schools
item.media:description: A man relaxed last week near a mural under an overhanging footpath along the coast in Sliema, Malta.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Most cities denounce, or tolerate, painting on public property. But on this Mediterranean island, the process is not only encouraged, it is funded.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GRIFFITHS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Nicolas Sarkozy Is Back, but France Has Changed
item.description: Does his country really want a divisive arsonist fighting its fires?
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Hero’s Burial for a Long-Dead Dictator
item.description: The Philippines’ new president wants to move Ferdinand Marcos’s body to a cemetery for heroes. It’s an affront to our history.
item.dc:creator: MIGUEL SYJUCO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Editorial: A Non-Contest at the World Bank
item.description: The lack of competition for the top job represents a lost opportunity to use the election as a forum to debate the institution’s future.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
